physicalObject: black insulated water bottle with Tesla logo
proxyLocation: left side of the first snapshot’s table, standing upright
utilizationMethod: Grip the bottle around its narrow neck with the thumb on one side and 2–3 fingers on the opposite side. The neck’s ~3 cm diameter gives a rounded rod-like feel that approximates the mug’s handle, while the bottle’s filled mass and off-center weight create a similar downward torque when you lift, tilt, and set it down.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This mug serves as a drinking vessel, designed to be grasped by the handle
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate weight that feels substantial since it's full. As well as a rotational moment around their grip point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a relatively thin, slender rod approximately 2 cm in diameter. User should sense the handle's curved arc and rounded cross-section.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user approaches the mug by slipping 2–3 fingers (typically index, middle, ring) through the loop-shaped handle while the thumb opposes them on the outer rim of the handle—essentially a relaxed precision-to-power hybrid grip. The handle’s rounded 2 cm-diameter rod dictates that the fingers wrap in a gentle curl rather than a flat pinch. Once secured, the user lifts the mug using elbow flexion and slight wrist ulnar deviation to keep the cup upright, immediately noticing a center-of-mass that sits a few centimeters to the left of the fingers (toward the liquid volume), giving a subtle rotational torque that must be countered. Typical manipulation includes: 1) lifting toward the mouth, 2) tilting about the handle axis to pour, and 3) setting it down with a controlled vertical descent. The mug’s response is rigid, with no deformation, but its inertia changes perceptibly as liquid level changes—heavier when full, lighter after drinking, and producing a modest slosh delay when the orientation is changed quickly.

physicalObject: white cardboard tube (empty paper roll core)
proxyLocation: center-back of the first snapshot’s table, standing vertically
utilizationMethod: Slip 2–3 fingers completely through the hollow tube so the fingers wrap its inner wall and the thumb rests outside. The 4 cm circular opening functions as a fixed loop; lifting the tube generates a perceptible moment arm similar to lifting a handled cup—even more so if the user imagines liquid weight on the far side.

physicalObject: chrome cylindrical calibration weight
proxyLocation: bottom-left of the first snapshot’s table
utilizationMethod: Place the thumb on the flat top and curl 2–3 fingers underneath the weight’s shoulder, emulating fingers inside a handle with the mug mass hanging below. The dense metal provides the required ‘full-mug’ mass and a clear rotational pull that must be countered while tilting.

physicalObject: black insulated water bottle with Tesla logo
proxyLocation: left side of the table in Snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Grip the very bottom of the bottle so the main mass sits above your fist. This hand-low, weight-high arrangement gives a forward-heavy feel similar to an axe head on a handle. Swing the bottle in a chopping arc; the metal body’s inertia provides noticeable resistance and a short jolt when you abruptly stop, approximating the head-heavy momentum of the virtual axe.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user uses a firm power grip around the lower third of the wooden handle, fingers wrapping fully and thumb locked, sometimes augmenting with the support hand higher up for two-handed swings. To chop, the dominant hand acts as a pivot while the shoulders and trunk generate a broad downward or diagonal arc; wrist pronation/supination fine-tunes blade alignment moments before impact. Because the mass is concentrated in the metal head, the user feels a pronounced forward weight that encourages a pendulum-like swing; beginning the motion requires effort but once moving the momentum carries through, forcing the user to arrest the motion after the virtual bite. Upon impact the axe stops abruptly in the VR scene, implying a short jolt that the user must absorb, after which the tool may either embed (requiring a tug and rearward pull) or rebound slightly depending on the simulation. Throughout, the cylindrical handle provides a consistent tactile reference with no perceptible compliance.

physicalObject: white cardboard tube (empty paper roll core)
proxyLocation: center-back of the table in Snapshot 1
utilizationMethod: Hold the tube near its lower end with a full fist grip. Although light, its diameter approximates a wooden handle. Encourage users to exaggerate swing speed so aerodynamic drag plus the tube’s length create a faint inertial pull that hints at an axe swing.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This axe serves as a chopping tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass with pronounced head-heavy inertia.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user uses a firm power grip around the lower third of the wooden handle, fingers wrapping fully and thumb locked, sometimes augmenting with the support hand higher up for two-handed swings. To chop, the dominant hand acts as a pivot while the shoulders and trunk generate a broad downward or diagonal arc; wrist pronation/supination fine-tunes blade alignment moments before impact. Because the mass is concentrated in the metal head, the user feels a pronounced forward weight that encourages a pendulum-like swing; beginning the motion requires effort but once moving the momentum carries through, forcing the user to arrest the motion after the virtual bite. Upon impact the axe stops abruptly in the VR scene, implying a short jolt that the user must absorb, after which the tool may either embed (requiring a tug and rearward pull) or rebound slightly depending on the simulation. Throughout, the cylindrical handle provides a consistent tactile reference with no perceptible compliance.

physicalObject: black selfie stick with extendable metal rod and phone holder
proxyLocation: top left of the yellow table in Snapshot 3
utilizationMethod: Collapse the telescopic rod halfway and grasp the foam handle at its lowest third. The protruding rod and heavier phone clamp at the far end create a clear forward-heavy inertia. Performing broad, diagonal swings recreates the momentum buildup and abrupt stop of an axe more faithfully than any other object in the scene.

physicalObject: transparent plastic cup

utilizationMethod: Insert three fingers inside and curl them so the rim rests against the palm, providing a pseudo-cylindrical grip. The cup’s lightness allows users to focus on wrist pronation/supination accuracy while visual cues in VR supply the missing weight.

physicalObject: black insulated water bottle with Tesla logo
proxyLocation: left side of the table
utilizationMethod: Grasp the bottle near its base so the capped end becomes the effective head of the hammer. This places most of the mass away from the hand, producing a noticeably head-heavy feel. Swing the bottle with a wrist-and-elbow motion exactly as you would the virtual hammer; the cylindrical body under the palm matches the required power-grip outline while the inertia of the metal bottle creates convincing lag during acceleration and deceleration.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This hammer serves as a striking tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel significant mass concentrated in the head, creating a distinctly head-heavy sensation when wielding the hammer.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical and substantial grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The hammer is grasped with a classic carpentry power grip near the end of the handle: all four fingers wrap and the thumb locks across or alongside them. The head-heavy inertia is felt immediately; small wrist movements lag behind the handle, so the user instinctively employs larger elbow and shoulder motions to raise and accelerate the tool. Striking involves a quick downward swing with wrist flexion just before impact to maximize head velocity. On contact the VR scene depicts a sudden stop accompanied by a brief recoil or bounce, signaling a high-frequency jolt that the user counterbalances by tightening grip and dampening with forearm muscles. Secondary interactions include light taps achieved by half-speed swings and grip repositioning closer to the head for increased control. The handle outline remains rigid and uniform, serving as the main tactile cue.

physicalObject: white cardboard tube (empty paper roll core)
proxyLocation: center-back of the table
utilizationMethod: Grip the tube close to one end so the longer portion extends forward as the faux hammer head. Although lightweight, the hollow length shifts the center of gravity away from the hand just enough to feel a slight moment when swinging. Users can still practice the full elbow-driven arc and wrist snap while feeling a rigid cylindrical handle.

physicalObject: chrome cylindrical calibration weight

The emphasis here is on conveying the hammer’s inertia at the moment of strike.

physicalObject: black insulated water bottle with Tesla logo
proxyLocation: left side of the first table, standing upright
utilizationMethod: Grasp the lower half of the bottle as the sickle’s short wooden handle. Swing the bottle in small semicircular pulling motions; the bottle’s forward-leaning weight (lid end) gives slight front inertia similar to the curved blade.

virtualObjectInfo.usage: This sickle serves as a harvesting and cutting tool
virtualObjectInfo.inertia: User should feel moderate forward-weighted inertia concentrated in the curved blade, but distributed along the arc rather than at a single point.
virtualObjectInfo.outline: User should feel a cylindrical grip that requires a firm grasp around the handle's circumference.
virtualObjectInfo.interactionDeduction: The user grasps the short, cylindrical handle with a firm but slightly choked-up power grip; because the curved blade extends forward and to the side, the wrist is naturally pronated so the palm faces slightly upward, allowing the blade to hook vegetation. Interaction consists of sweeping, semi-circular pulling motions towards the body, generated by elbow flexion and shoulder adduction. The distributed mass along the crescent blade gives a modest forward bias—less dramatic than an axe—but still creates noticeable centrifugal force when swinging quickly, encouraging follow-through. At the moment the blade intersects virtual stalks, the simulation halts or slows movement, conveying resistance as though slicing. The user then resets by rotating the forearm outward and repeating. Fine wrist rotations are used to angle the blade for different cut depths, all the while maintaining a rigid, non-compliant handle outline.

physicalObject: white cardboard tube (empty paper roll core)
proxyLocation: center-back of the first table, standing vertically
utilizationMethod: Hold the tube near one end like a handle and imagine the opposite end as the start of the blade. Its light weight lets the user perform quick sweeping motions while still maintaining the required pronated power grip around a cylindrical surface.

Fine wrist rotations are used to angle the blade for different cut depths, all the while maintaining a rigid, non-compliant handle outline.
